before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"ca3tg","text":"Before starting, prepare stock solutions/reagents as described in the section Preparation of Stock Solutions (Steps 1-4).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"8v1sf","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"fanes","text":"This protocol accompanies Expansion Sequencing (ExSeq), and describes the tissue preparation for Targeted ExSeq. The steps described here are a generalization of the protocols used for figures 4-6 of the paper, and represent our recommendations for future users of the technology. Fig. 1 shows the structure of the protocol schematically.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":281,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":26,"length":20}],"data":[]},{"key":"u9js","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dk9jr","text":"There are three possible tissue preparation routes described in this protocol that are applicable to different experimental systems. Option (A): harvesting tissue from model organisms that can be transcardially perfused with PFA, followed by sectioning using a vibratome. We typically use this workflow for work on mouse brain sections (see figures 4-5 of ExSeq paper). Option (B): transcardially perfusing with PFA, followed by cryoprotection and cryosectioning. We occasionally use this protocol for work on mouse brain sections. Option (C): snap-freezing fresh tissue (i.e., human tumor biopsy samples, or freshly harvested tissue from mice), followed by cryoprotection and cryosectioning (see figures 2 and 6 of ExSeq paper).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3s48e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bjqqq","text":"The final result of options (A), (B), and (C) is the preparation of fixed tissue sections (either on a glass slide or free-floating). The protocols then briefly converge for optional antibody staining, treatment with LabelX, a chemical that enables anchoring of RNA to the expansion microscopy (ExM) hydrogel, followed by casting of the the ExM gel. There are minor differences in these steps between free-floating and slide-mounted tissue sections, which are noted in the individual steps. The next step, digestion, is tissue-type dependent and may require some optimization for your tissue type. We provide two potential options here: (1) a gentle digestion for tissues such as mouse brain, and (2) a harsh digestion for non-brain tissues such as tumor biopies. The protocols then converge again for the rest of the process.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6cgq7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"brpjq","text":"After digestion, the gels are expanded and re-embedded within a second non-expanding hydrogel to lock in the sample size. The carboxylates within the expansion gel are then chemically passivated, enabling enzymatic reactions to be performed within the gel. The samples are now ready for library preparation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cilq7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"esqrg","text":"In more detail:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a32kd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"81kr4","text":"Steps 1-4 describe the preparation of reagents for downstream steps. The protocol begins either along options (A)/(B), the Transcardial PFA perfusion path (Step 5, continuing to vibratome sectioning in Steps 6-7 for option (A), or cryotome sectioning in Steps 9-10 for option (B)), or along option (C), the Fresh Frozen path (Step 8, continuing to cryotome sectioning in Steps 9-10).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"srmd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"81au7","text":"The protocols then converge for optional antibody staining (Step 11), followed by LabelX anchoring (Step 12), optional sample trimming (Step 13), and formation of the expansion microscopy gel (Step 14). The details of the digestion step are tissue-type dependent (Step 15). The protocol then concludes with expansion (Step 16), re-embedding (Step 17), passivation, and optional trimming (Steps 18-19).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"aegfr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c6leh","text":"This protocol was used to profile human metastatic breast cancer biopsies as a part of the Human Tumor Atlas Pilot Project (HTAPP). The tissue for this work was collected (see HTAPP-specific tissue collection protocol). The tissue sections were then frozen, cryosectioned, post-fixed, and permeabilized (following steps 9-10). No antibody staining was performed (skipping optional step 11). The sections were then treated with LabelX and gelled (steps 12-14). The gels were then digested using the robust digestion option in steps 15-16. The samples were then re-embedded, passivated, and trimmed (following steps 17-19).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"2AEACBB0A95F11EBB8A685B496AA9D98","height":364,"id":188840,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"d2vtj","text":"Figure 1. Flowchart of targeted ExSeq tissue preparation workflow.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Targeted_ExSeq_Brain_Tissue_Preparation_Flowchart_v0.2.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2pk9yv6.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2pi9yv6.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2pj9yv6.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2ph9yv6.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"35FA7C10AF8911EA99DC0F3AB7272942","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33509999/"}}}}

This protocol is Subject to IP Restrictions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"1524F46CA7CC11EBA91D0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://humantumoratlas.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Approved_HTAN-DMSA.pdf"}}}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"3bnm5","text":"This protocol significantly builds upon the tissue preparation from Expansion FISH (Chen*, Wassie*, et al. (2016)). A highly detailed Expansion FISH protocol (along with other expansion microscopy protocols) with detailed debugging advice has been published (Asano*, Gao*, Wassie* et al. (2018)). Prospective users are very strongly encouraged to review that protocol, as it overlaps significantly with steps 5-16 of this protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":297,"length":134}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":84,"length":29},{"key":1,"offset":259,"length":35}],"data":[]},{"key":"fe0si","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"snj1","text":"All reagents used should be RNAse-free. We have provided specific product numbers in the materials section. Of particular note, \"water\" always refers to UltraPure Water (nuclease-free).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ddj7c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9rpj2","text":"Because the volumes used for each of the steps will vary dramatically on the size of the containers used, the majority of the volumes for solutions have been standardized to 1 mL for ease of scaling. Similarly, wash volumes will also vary significantly depending on the size of the container, and are not listed explicitly. In general, wash volumes should be significantly larger than the size of the sample being washed. As a few examples: for 1-2 free floating sections in an Eppendorf tube, the wash volume would be 500 to 1000 μL; for sections on a slide in a well (as described in the protocol), the wash volume would be ~200 μL; for gels in a 4-well plate, the wash volume would be 5 mL.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"AD184580AF8D11EA99DC0F3AB7272942","url":"https://www.nature.com/articles/nmeth.3899"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"8F90F4C0AF8E11EA99DC0F3AB7272942","url":"http://syntheticneurobiology.org/publications/publicationdetail/299/25"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5d2af","text":"Preparation and Casting of Expansion Gel","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":40}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5gp3g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"efgmt","text":"The expansion gel is formed by free radical polymerization throughout the entire specimen volume. The sample is first pre-incubated with gelling solution, containing gel monomers (StockX), a free radical scavenger (4HT), a free radical polymerization accelerator (TEMED), and a free radical polymerization initiator (APS). The presence of 4HT and the pre-incubation temperature of   prevents premature gelation, allowing the monomers to diffuse into the tissue. When the temperature is raised, gelation occurs. Note that oxygen inhibits gelation, so avoiding air bubbles and backfilling the gelation chamber to maximally separate the tissue from any air is important.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":381,"length":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"E5A2FE70AF8F11EA99DC0F3AB7272942","id":"48295","label":"","temperature":"4","unit":10}}}}

Once thawed, keep solutions in a cold freezer block or on ice. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cd2p3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c11kt","text":"Mix StockX, 4HT, TEMED, and APS at a 47:1:1:1 ratio in an Eppendorf tube. Add 4HT, TEMED, and APS to StockX in that order, taking care to vortex between each addition, and keeping the solution in the cold freezer block.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fq9vk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8f1aq","text":"Suggested volumes: if the samples are free-floating in an Eppendorf or 24/48-well plate, 400 μL total should be sufficient. If the samples are attached to a slide, 200 μL should be sufficient. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fs58j","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"efnm3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"aasjr","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"tables","mutability":"","data":{"cellsMeta":{"0_0":"","0_1":"","0_2":"","0_3":"","1_0":"","1_1":"","1_2":"","1_3":"","2_0":"","2_1":"","2_2":"","2_3":"","3_0":"","3_1":"","3_2":"","3_3":"","4_0":"","4_1":"","4_2":"","4_3":"","5_0":"_dt-bold","5_1":"","5_2":"_dt-bold","5_3":""},"colWidths":[144,114,72,113],"data":[["","Stock solution concentration (w/v)","Amount","Final concentration (w/v)"],["Stock X solution","n/a","188 µl","n/a"],["4HT stock solution","0.5%","4 µl","0.01%"],["TEMED stock solution","10%","4 µl","0.2%"],["APS stock solution","10%","4 µl","0.2%"],["Total",null,"200uL",null]],"guid":"60A062E2ABB911EA80890A58A9FEAC2A","legend":"","mergeCells":[],"rowHeights":[23,23,23,23,23,23],"show_headers":true}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"aqn2j","text":"Pre-incubation of Sections with Gelling Solution","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":48}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d29j1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a33ui","text":"Transfer free-floating tissue sections from PBS to the gelling solution using a paintbrush. Transfer the Eppendorf tube/plate to the fridge for   at  , ideally in/on a pre-chilled cold block.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":144,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":149,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"1c0cp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5sj9b","text":"For sections on slides, pipette out as much PBS as possible from the well, tilting the slide to help pull PBS into droplets. Pipette 100-150 μL gelling solution onto the tissue, forming a bulging well. Place the slides in a 4-well plate and transfer to the fridge  for   at  , ideally on top of a pre-chilled cold block.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":269,"length":1},{"key":3,"offset":274,"length":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"duration","mutability":"","data":{"duration":1800,"guid":"369BBE10ABB811EAA6B81538CA8FF5D5","id":"79029","label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"3F6BE830ABB811EAA6B81538CA8FF5D5","id":"48296","label":"","temperature":"4","unit":10}},"2":{"type":"duration","mutability":"","data":{"duration":1800,"guid":"0D477650ABB911EA80890A58A9FEAC2A","id":"79030","label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null,"temperature":"4","unit":10}},"3":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"0D4775A1ABB911EA80890A58A9FEAC2A","id":"48297","label":"","temperature":"4","unit":10}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7516v","text":"Preparation of Gelation Chamber","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":31}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1u9hh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f4ru4","text":"Place two spacers, separated by ~10-15 mm on top of a glass slide. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d4gtb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"llgu","text":"Note: For free-floating tissue sections, the spacers can be placed while the sections are pre-incubating.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e1af6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1f6v6","text":"Note: For sections on slides, this step is performed at the end of preincubation, on the glass slide holding the section. The majority of the pre-incubation gelation solution should be removed at this stage, but the tissue section should remain covered with gelation solution. If an adhesive sticker was used to form a chamber, peel it off the glass slide. If a hydrophobic pen was used to form the chamber, scrape away the hydrophobic pen residue using a razor blade, taking to care to scrape away from the tissue.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4k5eh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7ad3q","text":"Note: Spacers can be, for example, thickness #0 coverslips (100 μm), or a single pieces of Scotch tape (~60 μm thick). For 50 μm sections or thinner, either Scotch tape or thickness #0 coverslip is fine. For thicker sections, a coverslip of appropriate thickness should be used. For first time users, we recommend using thickness #0 coverslips, as the thicker gels are easier to handle.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"95kbj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a2r30","text":"Note: If coverslips are used, a 1 μL droplet of water can be pipetted onto the slide before placing the coverslip to promote better adherence between the coverslip and the glass.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2idbj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"74q4r","text":"Note: If Scotch tape is used as a spacer, the excess tape should be cut so as to leave no excess overhang off the edge of the slide.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bdbds","text":"Construction of Gelation Chamber","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":32}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1fcrk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cg3gt","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"f0fqf","text":"For free-floating tissue sections: When the pre-incubation is complete, pipette a droplet of gelling solution from the pre-incubation solution to the center of the chamber. Then, use a paintbrush to transfer the tissue section from the Eppendorf tube to the gelation chamber.  If necessary, gently unroll/unfold the tissue with the paintbrush to flatten the tissue. Pipette an additional droplet of gelling solution on top of the gel.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1u51b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"equ2p","text":"For sections on slides: ensure that the tissue is covered with a droplet of gelling solution, but that there is not an excess of solution that may spill over when the lid of the gelling chamber is lowered.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ach4m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8gdj9","text":"Gently lower a coverslip or a slide on top of the gelling chamber, forming the lid. The lid should be lowered from one side to the other, i.e. so that the one edge of the lid is first lowered onto one of the spacers, and the second edge is slowly lowered onto the other spacer. The droplet on top of the sample will make contact with the lid and spread out over the tissue.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9amht","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7bagm","text":"It is critical that bubbles near the tissue section be avoided during this process. If bubbles occur, the lid can be removed and the lowering can be attempted again.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5naai","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cvbe5","text":"After lowering the lid, the gelation chamber should be back-filled by pipetting additional gelation solution into the gap between the lid and the base slide. The gelling solution will spread to fill the chamber via capillary action. Fig. 2 shows the final setup of the gelation chamber.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":233,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8dupe","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3l0im","text":"Take care not to overfill the chamber -- the lid should not be floating. The lid coverslip should be at least thickness #2 (200 μm) to avoid bending of the coverslip, leading to a non-flat gel. If there is spillage, the excess solution can be wiped away with a KimWipe. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1lf3h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a1tbb","text":"These steps should be completed within 5 minutes to avoid premature gelation. Eppendorf tubes containing tissue/gelling solution should be kept on a cold-block until use to minimize warming.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"389928D0AC1E11EBB8A685B496AA9D98","height":420,"id":188848,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"ekdoe","text":"Figure 2. Sketch of gelling chamber for casting the expansion gel. (A) Longitudinal cross-section of gelling chamber. Tissue is orange, spacers are dark blue, gelling solution is light blue. (B) Top-down view of same gelling chamber from (A).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"First_Gelation_Chamber_Design.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2pu9yv6.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2ps9yv6.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2pt9yv6.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2pr9yv6.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ar7rj","text":"Gelation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"av3nc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"678d0","text":"Place the gelation chamber into a humidified container and incubate for   at  .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":72,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":77,"length":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"duration","mutability":"","data":{"duration":7200,"guid":"DEA0AE47ABBD11EA80890A58A9FEAC2A","id":"79031","label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"duration":7200,"guid":"DEA0AEFEABBD11EA80890A58A9FEAC2A","id":"48298","label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null,"temperature":"37","unit":10}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"33lk5","text":"Digestion","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ei0g1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dg8tt","text":"To enable isotropic expansion, mechanical homogenization is performed by digesting proteins in the tissue-gel composite with Proteinase-K.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dptue","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"122t9","text":"The recommended digestion protocol is highly tissue-type dependent. We provide two digestion protocols here -- one for tissues that require a mild digestion to expand (i.e. mouse brain), and one for tissues that require a robust digestion to expand (most non-brain tissues, including human tumor biopsies and mouse tumor models).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9lgdv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1rrfk","text":"For the robust digestion, a chaotropic salt (guanidine hydrochloride) is included to denature proteins and increase their accessibility for Proteinase-K digestion. In addition, increased temperature and digestion duration are used to promote increased digestion.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dn6qu","text":"Preparing Digestion Buffer","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ff2gu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9ddkl","text":"Prepare the appropriate volume (described below) of either a Mild 1X Digestion Mix or a Robust 1X Digestion Mix, as is appropriate for the tissue. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4clgo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cmj6i","text":"Recipe for 1 mL of Mild 1X Digestion Mix (containing NaCl and Proteinase-K):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"db4hd","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"co29b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fmoqp","text":"Recipe for 1 mL of Robust 1X Digestion Mix (containing Guanidine HCl and Proteinase-K):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2qifj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"nqk4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"djcjk","text":"Volume of digestion mix to prepare:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1s0rj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"97huk","text":"For free-floating sections: for 1-2 sections, digestion can be performed in 1 mL of 1X Digestion Mix in an Eppendorf tube. For more sections, a well of a 6-well plate is recommended, requiring 3-4 mL of 1X Digestion Mix. Additionally prepare an additional 0.5 mL of 1X Digestion Mix in a separate Eppendorf tube (Supplemental Digestion Mix). The supplemental Digestion Mix must have the appropriate salt (either NaCl or Guanidine HCl), but does not need Proteinase-K.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"73fgd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a0q7m","text":"For sections on slides (in 4-well plates): prepare 5 mL per slide of 1X Digestion Mix.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9639j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8egf5","text":"The total volume of the Digestion Mix used should be \u003e100 times the volume of the sample gel.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"tables","mutability":"","data":{"cellsMeta":{"A_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"A_6":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"B_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"C_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"D_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"}},"colTitles":["","","",""],"colWidths":[102,128,69,"100.4000015258789"],"data":[["Solution","Stock {"blocks":[{"key":"4mcv2","text":"Opening Gelling Chamber","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d3hke","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6d2a3","text":"Remove the humidified container from the incubator and remove the samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1bcp9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"13c5m","text":"Pry the lid off of the gelation chamber by inserting a razor blade from the side between the lid and the spacers. Take care that the gel adheres to either the lid or the base slide. If it is partly stuck to the lid and the base slide, wet a paintbrush with Supplemental Digestion Mix and gently peel the the gel off of one of the surfaces.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"hdsl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a6duh","text":"Make cuts between the gel and the spacers with the razor blade, then lift off the spacers in a similar fashion to the lid. Using the razor blade, trim away excess gel. Leave a small margin (~1 mm) around the tissue. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6uaf2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eltc9","text":"For free-floating sections: pipette ~100 μL of digestion buffer from the Supplemental Digestion Mix onto each gel. Also wet a paintbrush with Supplemental Digestion Mix. Wait 10-30 seconds for the buffer to wet the borders of the gel. Then, use the paintbrush to gently peel the gel off of the slide by slowly moving the paintbrush back and forth underneath the edge of the gel, gradually probing further underneath the gel until the entire gel lifts off. Transfer the gel to the container with 1X Digestion Mix (prepared in the previous sub-step) for digestion. If the digestion is being performed in a plate, add a few mL of water to another well to humidify the plate, then seal with parafilm.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"658s3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"amtal","text":"For sections on slides: after opening the gelling chamber, place the slide (with the gel on top) into a well of a 4-well plate, and add the 1X Digestion Mix (prepared in the previous sub-step), ensuring that the gel is fully submerged in digestion mix. Add a few mL of water to another well, then place back into a humidified container for the next steps.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d1s8a","text":"Option 1: Mild Digestion Conditions","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":35}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4arap","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5nm1n","text":"Mild digestion conditions (using 1X Mild Digestion Mix) were optimized around mouse brain slices. There are three options for mild digestion that perform comparably. The lower temperature digestion conditions are preferred, as they avoid accelerating RNA degradation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a9dlt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a1n5e","text":"    Option 1A: Digest    at  .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":22,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":28,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"gsju","text":"    Option 1B: Digest for   at  .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":26,"length":1},{"key":3,"offset":31,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"7sfr9","text":"    Option 1C: Digest for   at  . ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":26,"length":1},{"key":5,"offset":31,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"arq7m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7nj4n","text":"The gel will expand ~1.5X during digestion. {"blocks":[{"key":"e1c55","text":"Chemical Passivation of Carboxylic Acids","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":40}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3504k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eis8q","text":"To enable enzymatic reactions to be performed, carboxylic acids/carboxylates within the original expansion gel need to be chemically passivated by transforming the carboxylic acid functional group into non-charged amides. This is performed by using carbodiimide crosslinker chemistry to form amides bonds between the carboxylic acids and ethanolamine. Unpassivated gels inhibit enzymatics, possibly through chelation of essential ions or interactions between the negative charges of carboxylates and enzymes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"aellv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dpddl","text":"Passivation is performed in two steps, an activation step, using EDC-NHS at pH 6.5 to activate carboxylic acids, and a coupling step at pH 8.5 to efficiently form amide bonds with ethanolamine.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"er1d0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ih","text":"Volumes here for slides in 4-well plate; can scale up/down accordingly for different containers.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
